requirements:
Basic To-Do List Website Requirements
User Interface:

Simple input field to add new tasks quickly.

List display area showing tasks clearly.

Checkboxes or toggles to mark tasks as completed.

Edit and delete options for existing tasks.

Responsive design for use on both desktop and mobile devices.

Task Management:

Ability to add, edit, and delete tasks.

Mark tasks as complete or incomplete.

Option to prioritize or categorize tasks.

Save tasks persistently (local storage or backend database).

User Experience:

Clear visual differentiation between completed and pending tasks.

Easy navigation and intuitive controls.

Option to reorder tasks by drag and drop or priority.

Technical Requirements:

Responsive front-end using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Optional backend for user authentication and task storage (using database).

Cross-browser compatibility.

Performance optimized for fast load and smooth interactions.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to add new tasks to their to-do list through a simple text input field.
acceptance_criteria: When a user enters text into the input field and clicks the 'Add' button, the new task appears in the task list.
The input field is cleared after a task is successfully added.
The application prevents the user from adding empty tasks.

functional_requirements.description: The application must display the list of all created tasks.
acceptance_criteria: All tasks are displayed in a clear, vertical list.
Each task in the list displays its full description.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to mark a task as completed.
acceptance_criteria: Each task has a checkbox next to it.
Clicking the checkbox toggles the task's status between 'pending' and 'completed'.
Completed tasks are visually differentiated from pending tasks (e.g., with a strikethrough).

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to edit the description of an existing task.
acceptance_criteria: An 'Edit' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Edit' allows the user to modify the task's description.
The updated description is saved and displayed in the list.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to delete a task from the list.
acceptance_criteria: A 'Delete' button or icon is available for each task.
Clicking 'Delete' permanently removes the task from the list.

functional_requirements.description: The application must save the user's tasks so they are not lost between sessions.
acceptance_criteria: Tasks remain in the list even after the browser is closed and reopened.

functional_requirements.description: Users should be able to reorder tasks to reflect their priority.
acceptance_criteria: Users can drag and drop tasks to change their order in the list.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should load quickly and provide a smooth user experience without noticeable delays.
metrics: Initial page load time should be under 2 seconds.
UI interactions (add, edit, delete) should feel instantaneous (under 200ms).

non_functional_requirements.description: The interface should be intuitive and easy to navigate for users of all technical skill levels.
metrics: A new user can add, complete, and delete a task in under 60 seconds without instructions.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application must function correctly on the latest versions of major web browsers.
metrics: Full functionality is verified on the latest versions of Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Apple Safari.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application layout must adapt to various screen sizes, ensuring usability on both desktop and mobile devices.
metrics: The application is fully usable on screen widths ranging from 320px (mobile) to 1920px (desktop).
All interactive elements are easily clickable/tappable on mobile screens.

risks: Scope Creep: The initial requirements are simple, but there's a risk of adding more complex features (e.g., user accounts, due dates, sub-tasks) that would significantly extend the timeline.
Data Persistence: Using Local Storage is simple but ties the data to a single browser on a single device. Users could accidentally clear their browser data, leading to data loss.
Cross-Browser Compatibility: Minor differences in CSS or JavaScript implementation across browsers could lead to unexpected visual glitches or functional issues requiring extra testing and debugging.
assumptions: The initial version will use browser Local Storage for data persistence, as a backend is specified as optional.
User authentication and multi-user support are out of scope for the initial development phase.
The design will be minimalist and functional, without the need for custom graphics or complex animations.
The application is for personal use, so there are no collaboration or data-sharing features required.
